question: <image 1> The 1933 political cartoon shown above makes the point that
options: ['infighting within and among unions prevented their rise to economic power', 'government inspectors turned their backs to illegal repression of labor unions', 'attacks on unions were so well concealed that the government did not know where to begin its investigations', 'from their beginnings, labor unions were controlled by organized crime']
description:
The image is a black-and-white political cartoon titled "Strike-Breaking." It depicts two figures engaged in a physical altercation. One figure, labeled "STRIKE-BREAKING," is being forcefully subdued by another figure labeled "UNION-BUSTING." The "STRIKE-BREAKING" figure appears to be falling backward, with one leg kicked up in the air and arms flailing, while the "UNION-BUSTING" figure is holding onto them tightly, seemingly overpowering them. 

In the bottom right corner of the image, there is a smaller scene showing a man dressed as a detective or inspector, wearing a deerstalker hat and holding a magnifying glass. He is looking down at a newspaper labeled "LABOR NEWS," which he seems to be reading intently. The detective's posture suggests he is searching for clues or information related to the events depicted in the main part of the cartoon.

The overall composition of the cartoon suggests a commentary on the conflict between strike-breaking activities and union-busting efforts, with the smaller scene implying that the government or authorities (represented by the detective) are either unaware of or not actively investigating these issues.
